bestBHT.bht: God's gracious arrangements, His glory filled will, is the object of divine pleasure. It is His good pleasure, involving wisdom and prudence, that should be praised even when we cannot fully perceive it. It is wise to yield to the good pleasure of God, even when it goes against our own reasoning. Rather than directing our fury against God, we should find satisfaction in His will alone. The difference in receiving the Gospel is solely due to the good will and pleasure of God.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the emphatic and chosen term for expressing any object of divine complacency
the glory of it—not so much in the light of its own reasonableness as of God's absolute will that so it should be—had filled His soul
John Calvin: There is nothing which we yield to God with greater difficulty, than that his will shall be regarded by us as the highest reason and justice.
This is sober wisdom, to acquiesce in the good pleasure of God as alone equal to a thousand arguments.
Men direct their fury against Christ when, on learning that some are freely chosen, and others are reprobated, by the will of God, they storm because they find it unpleasant to yield to God.
Philip Schaff: Praise for His ‘good pleasure’ which involves His wisdom, prudence, and goodness.
When men deny these qualities or we cannot fully perceive them, we may still praise His ‘good pleasure.’
Praise His ‘good pleasure,’ as our Master did.
Archibald T. Robertson: Wellpleasing in thy sight (ευδοκια εμπροσθεν σου). "For such has been thy gracious will" (Weymouth).
John Gill: This is a reason which ought to satisfy everyone, and is better than ten thousand others that can be thought of, or devised by men.
This difference among men, with respect to the Gospel revelation, cannot be owing to natural sagacity, prudence, and penetration; for these things are with those from whom it is hid.
Nor to any foresight of their making a better use and improvement of such a revelation, but to the good will and pleasure of God only.

bhtAttempts.bht: God's gracious eternal arrangements, filled with His glory and absolute will, are the objects of divine complacency. His good pleasure, involving His wisdom, prudence, and goodness, should be praised even when we cannot fully perceive or understand His ways. It is sober wisdom to acquiesce in the good pleasure of God, even when it goes against our human reasoning or desires. Instead of directing our fury or storming against God, we should yield and find satisfaction in His will, which surpasses any other argument or humanly devised reason. The difference in reception of the Gospel revelation cannot be attributed to human qualities, but solely to the good will and pleasure of God.

God's gracious eternal arrangements, filled with His glory and absolute will, are the objects of divine complacency. His good pleasure, involving His wisdom, prudence, and goodness, should be praised even when we cannot fully perceive or understand His ways. It is sober wisdom to acquiesce in the good pleasure of God. Instead of directing our fury or storming against God, we should yield and find satisfaction in His will, which surpasses any other humanly devised reason. The difference in reception of the Gospel revelation is solely attributed to the good will and pleasure of God.

God's gracious arrangements, His glory filled will, is the object of divine pleasure. It is His good pleasure, involving wisdom and prudence, that should be praised even when we cannot fully perceive it. It is wise to yield to the good pleasure of God, even when it goes against our own reasoning. Rather than directing our fury against God, we should find satisfaction in His will alone. The difference in receiving the Gospel is solely due to the good will and pleasure of God.

God's gracious eternal arrangements and His absolute will bring Him delight. We should praise His good pleasure, which involves His wisdom, prudence, and goodness, even when we don't fully understand it. It is wise to accept God's will, even when it contradicts our own reasoning. Rather than becoming furious or storming against God, we should find satisfaction in His will alone. The difference in the reception of the Gospel is solely due to God's good will and pleasure, not human qualities.

God's gracious eternal arrangements, filled with His glory and absolute will, are the objects of divine complacency. His good pleasure, involving His wisdom, prudence, and goodness, should be praised even when we cannot fully perceive or understand His ways. It is sober wisdom to acquiesce in the good pleasure of God, even when it goes against our human reasoning or desires. Instead of directing our fury or storming against God, we should yield and find satisfaction in His will, which surpasses any other humanly devised reason.
